diseases.name: Common Cold
diseases.description: A viral infection of the upper respiratory tract (nose and throat). Usually harmless and self-limiting; most people recover within 7–10 days.
diagnostics: Rapid flu test (to rule out influenza)
diseases.references: CDC Common Cold. NIH MedlinePlus. For educational use only.

diseases.name: Influenza (Flu)
diseases.description: Contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses. Can cause mild to severe illness; high-risk groups may develop complications.
treatment: Antivirals (e.g. oseltamivir) if indicated and early
Symptomatic relief for fever and pain
diseases.references: CDC Influenza. WHO Flu. For educational use only.

diseases.name: Allergic Rhinitis (Hay Fever)
diseases.description: Inflammation of the nasal lining due to allergens (pollen, dust mites, pet dander). Seasonal or perennial.
diseases.references: AAAAI Allergic Rhinitis. NIH. For educational use only.

diseases.name: Migraine
diseases.description: Recurrent headache disorder, often one-sided and pulsating, with or without aura. Can be disabling.
treatment: Lifestyle: sleep, stress management, trigger avoidance
diseases.references: ICHD-3. AAN Migraine guidelines. For educational use only.

diseases.name: Tension-Type Headache
diseases.description: Most common primary headache. Typically bilateral, pressing/tightening quality, mild to moderate intensity.
treatment: Physical therapy for neck if relevant

diseases.name: Gastroenteritis (Acute)
diseases.description: Inflammation of the stomach and intestines, usually viral or bacterial. Leads to diarrhea, vomiting, and sometimes fever.
diagnostics: Stool studies if severe or prolonged
treatment: Antibiotics only if bacterial cause confirmed
diseases.references: CDC Viral Gastroenteritis. WHO. For educational use only.

diseases.name: GERD (Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease)
diseases.description: Chronic condition where stomach acid frequently flows back into the esophagus, causing symptoms and sometimes tissue damage.
diagnostics: Upper endoscopy if alarm symptoms or refractory
treatment: Lifestyle: weight loss, smaller meals, avoid triggers
diseases.references: ACG GERD guidelines. For educational use only.

diseases.name: Asthma
diseases.description: Chronic airway disease with reversible bronchoconstriction, inflammation, and variable airflow limitation.
diseases.references: GINA guidelines. NIH NHLBI. For educational use only.

diseases.name: Acute Bronchitis
diseases.description: Inflammation of the bronchial tubes, usually viral. Cough often lasts 1–3 weeks.
diseases.references: CDC Bronchitis. For educational use only.

diseases.name: Urinary Tract Infection (UTI)
diseases.description: Infection in any part of the urinary system (urethra, bladder, ureters, kidneys). More common in women.
treatment: Antibiotics per local guidelines and susceptibility
diseases.references: IDSA UTI guidelines. For educational use only.

diseases.name: Hypertension (High Blood Pressure)
diseases.description: Persistently elevated blood pressure. Major modifiable risk factor for cardiovascular and kidney disease.
treatment: Lifestyle: DASH diet, exercise, weight loss, limit alcohol/sodium
diseases.references: ACC/AHA Hypertension guidelines. For educational use only.

diseases.name: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus
diseases.description: Chronic metabolic disorder with hyperglycemia due to insulin resistance and/or relative insulin deficiency.
treatment: Additional agents (e.g. SGLT2i, GLP-1 RA) per guidelines
diseases.references: ADA Standards of Medical Care. For educational use only.

diseases.name: Anemia
diseases.description: Reduction in red blood cells or hemoglobin, leading to reduced oxygen-carrying capacity. Multiple causes (iron deficiency, B12, chronic disease, etc.).
diseases.references: ASH. NIH Anemia. For educational use only.
